head.supplied: Royal Society of Tasmania. ¶ Hobart ¶ , Nov. 16 ¶ 1896 ¶ . ¶ Dear Sir, ¶ ¶ I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letters of the […] ¶ October and 4th instant, ¶ also Report of a meeting of you...

div.p: From James Agnew to Alexander Macdonald
MU 95, box 11 (340/96), Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa, Wellington.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: center;
font-family: Geneva, Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: MS annotated: 'Copy of letter sent to A. C. Macdonald Esq. Hon. Sec. R.G.S.A. Melbourne'. MS registered at the office of the New Zealand Geological Survey on 30 December 1896, suggesting that Agnew had sent the copy to James Hector. The item is annotated: 'File'.

p.style: font-family: Geneva, Geneva; font-size: 12pt; text-align: end;

div.p:
I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letters of the […]
Blank left in MS. October and 4th instant,
Letters not found. also Report of a meeting of your Royal Geographical Society of Australasia. In reply, I am requ[ested] by the Council of the Royal Society of Tasmania to say, we are not yet in a position to offer [any] very definite suggestions as to a fitting memorial of the late Baron Von Müeller. But recognizing the fact that it will be of a National (Australasian) character, we think some difficulty could be avoided if the question as to the precise form of Memorial were relegated to such [a] nonprovincial body as the Australasian Association for the Advancement of Science. The Association would no doubt be extremely glad to receive from the various Societies within its scope any suggestions which might be offered, as one or more of these could scarcely fail to be of great value in indicating some scheme which would give general satisfaction. In order to avoid intercolonial jealousies, we […] it would be inadvisable that the memorial should be of such a character as to be necessarily attached to any special locality. This might contraindicate the foundation, which has been mooted, of a University Chair of Botany, but probably its great expense alone would render [any] testimonial of this kind, though appropriate in many ways, an impossibility. It has been suggested by Mr Maiden Director of the Botanical Gardens, Sydney, that a life of the Baron, accompanied by a complete Bibliography of his works (which at present does not exist) would be [of] general acceptance. This idea seems worthy of consideration, especially were it extended so as [to] embrace the erection of a suitable monument over the grave of our distinguished friend.
